title: Works of R. L. Stevenson. (Edinburgh edition.) [Edited by Sidney Colvin.]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: He was to pay no more visits till he had seen his father and made all well at home; Alan had been the only possible exception, and John had not time to go as far as Murrayfield. But here he was on Regent Terrace; there was nothing to prevent him going round the end of the hill, and looking from without on the Mackenzies' house.

title: Works of R. L. Stevenson. (Edinburgh edition.) [Edited by Sidney Colvin.]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Now, it chanced he had a friend, a publican in Queensferry Street, from whom, in view of the sacredness of the occasion, he thought he might extract a dram. Queensferry Street lies something off the direct road to Murrayfield. But then there is the hilly cross-road that passes by the valley of the Leith and the Dean Cemetery; and Queensferry Street is on the way to that.

title: Works of R. L. Stevenson. (Edinburgh edition.) [Edited by Sidney Colvin.]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: And the old butler removed his defences, remarking only, ' I thocht ye were that man.' But his master was not there; he was staying, it appeared, at the house in Murrayfield; and though the butler would have been glad enough to have taken his place and given all the news of the family, John, struck with a little chill, was eager to be gone. Only, the door was scarce closed again, before he regretted that he had not asked about 'that man.'

title: Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher.
author: Fletcher
snippet: "We spent the winter of 1842-43 at Murrayfield very quietly, as prudence was strongly enforced on me since my late illness.

title: Memoirs and correspondence of Francis Horner, M.P.
author: Horner, Francis
snippet: I am happy to hear your mother continues in health, and thank her for inquiring after me. I often think, I assure you, of the pleasant days I used to pass at Murrayfield; and often reflect, with lively, though indeed inadequate gratitude, of the kindness I have received from your family. Tell Mrs. Murray that this is the case ; I am anxious she should know it: as she once treated me with kindness, which I construed into regard, I should anxiously wish to preserve the esteem of so respectable a parent of the friend whom I love most.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: 1891 conscientious. Only, there 's the house at Murrayfield and a dead body in it. Glad the Ballads amused you.

title: Works of R. L. Stevenson. (Edinburgh edition.) [Edited by Sidney Colvin.]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: ' If you had written home,' replied the lady,' there would have been none of it. If you had even gone to Murrayfield reasonably sober, you would never have slept there, and the worst would not have happened. Besides, the whole thing began years ago.

title: Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher.
author: Fletcher
snippet: Dr. Davy returned from Constantinople and joined us at Murrayfield in January, 1842. A very few nights after his return I met with a bad accident by a fall down stairs.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Harmless barque ! I gather you ain't married yet, since your sister, to whom I ask to be remembered, goes with you. Did you see a silly tale, John Nicholson's Predicament, 1 or some such name, in which I made free with your home at Murrayfield ? There is precious little sense in it, but it might amuse. Cassell's published it in a thing called Yule-Tide years ago, and nobody that ever I heard of read or has ever seen YuleTide.
